doc.field: Natural Resource Inventory Table for Lakes and Large Rivers
Natural Resource Inventory Table for Lakes and Large Rivers

This dataset is a table of characteristics related to the ecological, recreational, and water supply uses of lakes and large rivers in the Twin Cities Metropolitan Area. Data on these characteristics are drawn from a variety of sources including the DNR and Met Council. This table also includes several calculated fields. Additional information about the source of these data is given in the Entity and Attribute section of this metadata. This tables can be linked to a geographic representation of lakes and large rivers through the Hydro_luse2000 data layer.
These data were created as a part of a natural resource inventory and assessment for the Twin Cities Metropolitan Area.

Data on these characteristics are drawn from a variety of sources including the DNR and Met Council. This table also includes several calculated fields. Additional information about the source of these data is given in the Entity and Attribute section of this metadata. This tables can be linked to a geographic representation of lakes and large rivers through the Hydro_luse2000 data layer.
These data were created as a part of a natural resource inventory and assessment for the Twin Cities Metropolitan Area.</abstract> <purpose>This dataset was developed as a resource for incorporating natural resource protection in to plans for accomodating future growth and development in the Twin Cities. The data are intended to provide a relative rank of the potential regional significance of lakes and large rivers for ecological, recreational, and water supply uses.</purpose> <supplinf>Twin Cities 7 County Metropolitan Area. No assessment of accuracy has been performed. Please refer to the Aquatic Resource Assessment Report for a discussion of the source data and the methods for additional information on attribute accuracy. Also, refer to the metadata for each source dataset listed in the report.</attraccr> </attracc> <logic>not applicable</logic> <complete>Entire seven county geographic area is covered.</complete> <posacc> <horizpa> <horizpar>not applicable</horizpar> </horizpa> <vertacc> <vertaccr>not applicable</vertaccr> </vertacc> </posacc> <lineage> <srcinfo> <srcscale /> </srcinfo> <procstep> <procdesc>The fields in this table provide descriptive information regarding the features contained in the hydro_luse2000 dataset. Several of these fields were created by spatially joining other datasets such as parks, rare and endangered species, sites of biological significance, and public water access sites to the hydro_luse2000 dataset. Other data such as trout information and water supply information were obtained from hard copy documents and added to the table manually. After all required externally derived data were joined to the hydro_luse2000 dataset, these additional fields were exported to this table and editted. Other fields representing the recreational importance and ecological importance were derived by applying criteria developed by the Metropolitan Council in consultation with several other agencies and organizations. Some field specific lineage information can be found in the attribute description section of this metadata.
Please refer to the Aquatic Resource Assessment Report for further details (Metropolitan Council Publication 32-03-015). This document can be obtained online from . . .</procdesc> </procstep> </lineage> </dataqual> <spdoinfo> <indspref>Lake ID</indspref> <direct /> <mgmg3obj /> <mgmg3til /> </spdoinfo> <spref> <horizsys>
<geograph> <latres /> <longres /> </geograph> <planar> <mapproj> <mapprojn /> <mgmg4par /> <otherprj /> </mapproj> <gridsys> <gridsysn /> <utm> <utmzone /> </utm> <spcs> <spcszone /> </spcs> <mgmg4coz /> <mgmg4adj /> </gridsys> <planci> <coordrep> <absres /> <ordres /> </coordrep> <distbrep> <distres /> </distbrep> <plandu /> </planci> </planar> <geodetic> <horizdn /> <ellips /> </geodetic> </horizsys> <vertdef> <altsys> <altdatum /> <altunits /> </altsys> <depthsys> <depthdn /> <depthdu /> </depthsys> </vertdef> </spref> <eainfo> <overview> <eaover>LAKE_ID: A unique 8-digit identifier for each lake polygon. The value of this field is the DNR Division of Water lake identification number (Dowlknum) if one has been assigned. Otherwise, the Lake_id is a unique sequential number (Autonumber).
AUTONUMBER: A unique 8-digit sequential number beginning with 99 to distinguish the number from the DNR lake ID number.
RNAME: The DNR registered name of the lake, if one exists.
BIODIV_SIG: Indicates whether an open water feature intersects a site of high biodiversity as identified in the Minnesota County Biological Survey (MCBS). Values are Y or N.
TROUT: Indicates whether a lake is a DNR designated trout lake. Large rivers are not designated. Values are Y or N.
NONMOBILE: The number of observations within the past 25 years, of rare, endangered, threatened or unusual aquatic species (heretofore referred to as R&E species) that are not mobile outside of an aquatic environment (e.g. fish, mollusks, etc.) associated with an open water feature.
MOBILE: The number of observations within the past 25 years of R&E species that are mobile outside of an aquatic environment (e.g. reptiles, birds, etc.) associated with an open water feature.
BIO_CLASS: A relative score summarizing the known biologically significant sites based on the Biodiv_sig, Trout, Nonmobile, and Mobile fields. The value is a 1, 2, or 3, with a value of three having the highest probability of important biological features.
CLARITY: The average of the satellite-estimated, summer-mean, water clarity depth (equivalent to the Secchi disk transparency depth). Details of the satellite water clarity estimation procedure can be found in Kloiber et al. (2002) in the journal Remote Sensing of Environment.
CLAR_CLASS: A relative water clarity rank based on the Clarity field. The value is a 1, 2, or 3, with a value of three being the best water clarity condition.
RIP_VEG: The fraction of the land area within 60 meters of the shoreline that is covered by natural vegetation. Values are experessed as real numbers.
RIP_CLASS: A relative rank based on the amount of natural vegetation in the riparian zone based on the Rip_veg field. The value is a 1, 2, or 3, with a value of three being the best natural vegetation cover.
PHYS_CLASS: A relative rank of the physical condition of the lake for ecological habitat based on the clarity class and the riparian vegetation class. The value is a 1, 2, or 3, with a value of three being the best habitat condition.
ECO_CLASS: A relative rank of the overall ecological condition of the lake based on the physical habitat condition (PHYS_CLASS) and the known probability of significant biological features (BIO_CLASS). The value is a 1, 2, or 3, with a value of three being the best overall ecological condition.
PARK: Indicates whether or not there is a public park adjacent to a water feature. Data for park locations was extracted from the Metropolitan Council's 2000 land use dataset. Values are Y or N.
PWA: Indicates whether or not there is a public water access(PWA) site for a water feature. Data on PWA provided by the DNR. Values are Y or N.
REC_CLASS: A relative score summarizing the regional recreational significance based on the Area_ac, Park, and Pwa fields. The value is a 1, 2, or 3, with a value of three being more regionally important for recreational use.
WS_CLASS: A relative score summarizing the regional water supply significance based on the criteria presented in the Regional Aquatic Assessment Procedures document. Data were obtained through a review of regional and local water supply plans on file at the Metropolitan Council. The value is a 1, 2, or 3, with a value of three being more regionally important for water supply use.
HU_CLASS: A relative rank of the overall human use significance of the lake based on the recreational and water supply significance. The value is a 1, 2, or 3, with a value of three being the most significant for overall human use. The human use class is the maximum of the recreational class and the water supply class.</eaover> <eadetcit>Data were developed by the Metropolitan Council with input from several other agencies and organizations. Please refer to the Aquatic Resource Assessment Report for further details (Metropolitan Council Publication 32-03-015). This document can be obtained online at http://www.metrocouncil.org/planning/environment/ara_report.pdf .</eadetcit> </overview> </eainfo> <distinfo> <distrib> <cntinfo> <cntperp> <cntper>Mark Kotz</cntper> <cntorg>Metropolitan Council</cntorg> </cntperp> <cntpos>GIS Database Administrator</cntpos> <cntaddr> <addrtype> mailing and physical address </addrtype> <address>390 Robert Street North</address> <city>St. Paul</city> <state>Minnesota</state> <postal>55101-1805</postal> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>651-602-1644</cntvoice> <cntfax>651-602-1674</cntfax> <cntemail>mark.kotz@metc.state.mn.us</cntemail> </cntinfo> </distrib> <resdesc>NRIALakesAndRiversTable</resdesc> <distliab>NOTICE: The Geographic Information System (GIS) Data to which this notice is attached are made available pursuant to the Minnesota Government Data Practices Act (Minnesota Statutes Chapter 13).
